title: Literature Review: Classical Pendulum Dynamics and Equations of Motion
summary: Comprehensive review of simple pendulum physics covering Newtonian and Lagrangian formulations, small-angle approximation, and exact elliptic-integral solutions.

references.title: A First Course in Differential Equations for Scientists and Engineers - Ch. 7: Nonlinear Systems
references.author: R. Herman
references.key_content: Derives the exact period T = (2*T0/pi)*K(k) where k=sin(theta0/2) and K is the complete elliptic integral of the first kind. Provides series expansion T = 2*pi*sqrt(L/g)*[1 + (1/4)k^2 + (9/64)k^4 + ...]. Also covers exact solution using Jacobi elliptic function sn.

references.title: Underactuated Robotics - Ch. 2: The Simple Pendulum
references.author: R. Tedrake (MIT)
references.key_content: Derives equations of motion via Lagrangian: m*L^2*theta_ddot + m*g*L*sin(theta) = Q, where Q includes damping and control torques. Covers state-space formulation and phase portrait analysis.

references.title: Pendulum (mechanics) - Wikipedia
references.author: Wikipedia contributors
references.key_content: Comprehensive reference covering: Newtonian derivation (F=ma), energy conservation, exact period via elliptic integrals, AGM-based computation T = 2*pi/M(1,cos(theta0/2))*sqrt(L/g), and the full nonlinear solution using Jacobi elliptic functions.

references.title: Exact solution for the nonlinear pendulum
references.author: Belendez et al.
references.key_content: Derives exact closed-form solutions for the nonlinear pendulum using Jacobi elliptic functions. Demonstrates that the effect of nonlinearity appears only in the amplitude-dependent frequency.

references.title: Oscillations of a simple pendulum with extremely large amplitudes
references.author: E.I. Butikov
references.key_content: Analyzes pendulum behavior for amplitudes approaching pi, including the separatrix behavior where the period diverges to infinity. Covers both oscillatory and rotational regimes.
